bibl.title: Letter from Henry Hanson to the Director of Public Health, March 30, 1921

div1.p: Hanson writes about the inappropriate handling of vaccine.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Hanson to the Director of Public Health, March 30, 1921
div1.opener:
Chiclayo, Peru. March 30, 1921.
The Director of Public Health,
The Ministerio de Fomento,
Lima, Peru.
Dear Sirs:
div1.p:
There seems to have been considerable confusion about the
delivery of the Noguchi Vaccine which was ordered to this Department
by the International Health Board, and I would like to obtain certain
information in regard to this matter.

It was first understood here that the vaccine would be sent to
the Banco Mercantil Americano, and Mr. Bonzi had made all arrangements
to receive the vaccine and take care of it according to the instructions
from the International Health Board. For some unknown reason the directions
for the delivery of the vaccine were changed, and as a consequence no one
was on hand at the time to receive the vaccine when the ship was in port.
The vaccine therefore went on to Pacasmayo, where it was taken ashore
and later transported overland by way of Cayalti to this place. For a
product which should be kept constantly on ice this is not the proper way
to handle it. It is necessary that I know more about this matter so as to
enable me to fix the responsibility in this matter. Please write full details.

Furthermore according to the correspondence which I saw in Lima
there ought to be more vaccine on hand there. The vaccine which was turned over
to me consisted only of three 20cc bottles of vaccine and four bottles of ser-
um. Is there no other stock of this vaccine on hand in Lima?

In the future I believe it will be better to all materials of this
kind directed to the Central Office with previous notification, and we will
arrange to send some responsible party aboard to receive it personally.
